awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will enable students to attend the Verification Mentoring Workshop (VMW 2017) which will be co-located with the International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV) in Heidelberg (Germany), July 22-28, 2017. CAV is one of the premier conferences in computer science, dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis methods for hardware and software systems. The purpose of Verification Mentoring Workshop is to provide mentoring and career advice to early-stage graduate students, to attract them to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification. Funded students will benefit greatly from the opportunity to engage in the critical technical, professional, and social exchanges that both conferences foster.

Computer-aided verification covers a broad range of applications, from ensuring the correctness and safety of computer systems, to improving design and development productivity. The funded students will attend CAV, a top conference where they will learn about current research problems and interact with leaders in the field, and the VMW workshop which will focus on mentoring and career advice specific to early-stage graduate students who aim to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification.

por.por_cntn:
Society is increasingly reliant on computer and information systems. The area of computer-aided verification and formal methods is thriving and growing in computer science, fueled by the needs to develop safe and correct computer and information systems on one hand, and improve designer and development productivity on the other. The International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV) is one of the premier conferences in this area, dedicated to the advancement of the theory and practice of computer-aided formal analysis methods for hardware and software systems.

In 2017, the CAV conference was held in Heidelberg, Germany, July 22-28. We organized the Third Verification Mentoring Workshop (VMW) co-located with CAV. The purpose of VMW is to provide mentoring and career advice to early-stage graduate and senior undergraduate students, and to attract them to pursue research careers in the area of computer-aided verification. The full day workshop program was organized into multiple technical talks from academia and industry, and concluded with a panel and consisted of multiple breaks to promote interaction and an open Q&A session. The invited speakers comprised a mix of senior and junior leaders in the field. The invited speakers at the workshop gave students a broad overview of the area, introduced them to the wide range of career options, and provided career and mentoring advice. Many workshop participants also attended the CAV conference, where they learned about current research problems and interacted with leaders in the field. The conference comprised one full day of in-depth tutorials, followed by four days of technical sessions that include invited keynotes and presentations of papers.

In addition to the technical program both VMW and CAV included many social events that provided additional opportunities for interaction. In particular, we continued the CAV Buddy System. The idea is to pair each VMW student with a more experienced student buddy who is familiar with CAV. We set up the buddies in advance. We hoped that this would help the new students become more easily acquainted with others attending CAV. We also hope that everyone who got a buddy this year will become someone else’s buddy next year. We also introduced a women’s lunch for the VMW participants to promote more interaction between female participants. We also invited several senior female researchers in academia and industry with whom the participants could interact at a personal level.

We are grateful to NSF for their generous sponsorship of VMW. This sponsorship supported the travel of 11 US-based students to VMW and CAV 2017. Of these, 6 were women. The travel grant covered travel costs, workshop and conference registrations, meals, and a shared accommodation. The awardees were reimbursed actual travel costs. In addition to NSF sponsorship, we also received generous corporate support from the following companies: Microsoft Research, Amazon, Cadence. These corporate sponsorships enabled providing travel support to an additional 15 students based outside US, of which 6 were women.
